turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 159, Frederick C. Lynch, Petitioner, versus Winfred Overholser, Superintendent of St. Elizabeths Hospital.
Mr. Shea.
Mr. Arens, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
This case arises from the application of Section 301 of Title 24 of the D.C. Code.

The statutory provision in question provides for the mandatory commitment to a public mental hospital of all those, and I quote the statutory language, “acquitted solely on the ground that they were insane at the time of the commission of the act charged in the information or indictment.”
The petitioner, Coronel Lynch is an inmate of St. Elizabeths Hospital as a result of a commitment pursuant to the statutory provision.
Yet, the petitioner is not an ordinary beneficiary of an insanity acquittal, as these terms have been traditionally understood.
The petitioner is an inmate of St. Elizabeths Hospital as the result of an imposition upon him of an insanity defense which he resisted by every legal means at his disposal.
The petitioner in brief was compelled to submit to an insanity defense, the successful advancement of which was calculated to and did in fact result to his incarceration in a lunatic asylum.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did you represent him in the trial court, Mr. Shea?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I'm Mr. Arens, if Your Honor please.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Mr. Arens, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I did not represent him in the municipal court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: He had a lawyer, though.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: A lawyer was appointed to him at a later stage of the municipal court proceedings.
The facts of this case can very -- be very briefly summarized at an early stage of the municipal court proceedings.

The petitioner had no lawyer and may I say this, the petitioner who had never before been convicted of a criminal offense and who previously served honorably as a commissioned officer in the Armed Forces was charged with a violation of the Bad Check Law of the District of Columbia.This took place on November 6, 1959.
Specifically, the petitioner was charged with overdrawing his checking account by $100 and failing to make restitution within a period of five days.

And now, if it please the Court, he was arraigned before the municipal court and he lacked assistance of counsel at the time of his arraignment and it was at that time that a not guilty plea was entered for the petitioner by the court.

And it was at that time, if it please the Court, that petitioner was committed to the D.C. General Hospital Psychiatric Division for examination to determine his mental competency to stand trial pursuant to Section 301 of Title 24 D.C. Code.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would you mind stating the detailed -- that led to that commitment?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Your Honor, the record does not show what the precise basis of this commitment was.
I do not know.
I assume that some prima facie evidence of mental unsoundness had been presented to the municipal court.
The record does not show it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there any assumption or presumption to be entered through him?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe we can --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All I want to know is if the judge could do this out of hand just capriciously?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I do not believe the municipal court judge acted capriciously in this case.I believe he acted in good faith, however, erroneously.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then he must have --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- had some basis for it.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is no doubt in my mind that his attention must have been called to the fact that the petitioner have had a previous history of mental hospitalization which of course is not denied.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There was no transcript at all.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There was no transcript, Mr. Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What's the -- statute provides so far as commitment for observation at the time of arraignment?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Section 301 (a) of Title 24 of the D.C. Code provides that upon prima facie evidence of insanity or incompetency to stand trial or upon personal observation, the judge may order the commitment of an individual defendant charged with a crime by either an indictment or an information for a reasonable period of time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It must be assumed that the conditions of the section were satisfied.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe it can be validly assumed these conditions were satisfied although as an act of due process of law, I would respectfully submit that assistance of counsel was necessary even at that early stage and that assistance of counsel was unavailable at that time to the petitioner, for what is clear was the petitioner's commitment for observation was not challenged essentially because petitioner lacked legal representation at that time.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When he entered his plea of not guilty, did he have counsel?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, he did not.
And the record --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does the statute leave room for challenge of the judge's action?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The statute specifically provides for an opportunity of challenging commitment to a mental hospital by habeas corpus.
I believe that's --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I'm talking now about this preliminary commitment for observation (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is no --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- before an arraignment.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is no specific statement addressed to that particular point in the statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because the statute gives the judge power to do it, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Upon prima facie evidence of mental insanity.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And so far as -- upon observation.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct and may I say, if Your Honor please, there has been at least one case in which an individual charged with a minor traffic violation found herself in the psychiatric ward of a public hospital upon the basis of that particular statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you saying this to shock us?
Does that seem shocking to you?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I'm saying this essentially to illustrate the scope to which this particular statute has been subjected in the day-to-day operations of municipal wards.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's -- those are the terms of the statute, aren't they?
They're not confined to the nature or magnitude or gravity of the crime that the person is --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they're not.
They're not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Charged at all.
They are directed to the person's condition not to the magnitude of the offense that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I want to know exactly what the proposition is that you're tendering to the Court.
Suppose a man is -- appears before -- been brought before a magistrate and he gives evidence of being a raving maniac, if one may assume that such evidence may overtly be made.

Does the judge -- must the judge stop then and there and appoint counsel and go through the proceedings of having the counsel raise the question or may he at once make arraignments for the transfer of that individual to St. Elizabeths?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Under the statute as it stands at present there is no question but that the judge may at once make arrangements for the transfer of that particular individual to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you say -- and do you -- is your submission that that is violative of the Due Process Clause?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe that assistance of counsel should be available even at that stage although this is not the central part of the petitioner's case.
In fact, I do not rely upon --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you do not know -- we do not know on what valid or substantial or satisfying basis the commitment here was made.
He may not have been a raving maniac, if that term is still permissible in these days, but may have been a basis just as -- justified on.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, indeed, there may have been a basis, but not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is not your main point.
Would you mind --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- stating exactly what it is you're tendering to the Court?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
If I may be permitted to recount the subsequent history of the judicial proceedings --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I -- perhaps one could understand better what the significance of the facts are if you will tell us with reference to what are to be judged.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Very well, Your Honor.
The major issue before this Court, as I see it, is this.
May the prosecution in a system of adversarial justice prevent a competent defendant from waiving any defense available to him and compel him to assert a defense of its choosing to his disadvantage.
Specifically and more narrowly applied to this case the issue may be stated as follows.

May the prosecution compel the defendant to present the insanity defense, the successful advancement of which ends in disaster because a person who successfully asserts insanity must be committed to a mental institution for an indefinite period.

And because commitment to a mental institution, I respectfully submit is one of the major depravations inflicted by our society insofar as loss of liberty to speak of no other considerations is concerned.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But now why do you refer to that as a disaster?
It's a sad condition, but assuming that this person is mentally ill, why is it disastrous to send him to a mental institution to be cured?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I would suggest the procedure by which we determine whether or not this particular person is mentally ill be a rationale and fair procedure.
And I respectfully submit that the procedure employed by the municipal court in this case was neither.
It permitted of no fair assumption that this particular individual was in fact mentally ill and was dangerous to himself or others as of the time of the adjudication.
This was no civil commitment proceeding in which by fair preponderance of evidence, it was established that the defendant was sick at that time and that he needed hospitalization.

What took place in this case, if it please the Court, is a proceeding in which the commitment of the individual petitioner was made possible under a standard of proof requiring the raising of nothing more than a reasonable doubt concerning his mental health.
Confinement --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Isn't -- the point is that there's never yet been an affirmative determination that he is insane, whatever that means.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Mr. Justice Brennan, I wish I could've stated it that succinctly.
That is precisely --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there must be --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now -- go ahead.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There must be -- I probably was wrong to ask you to state your general proposition because there must be more to the facts than one rejection ceased of --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Indeed, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- because all you've told us specify is that the record doesn't show what the basis was on which the magistrate did make the commitment.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct, Your Honor, and may I say it is not the original commitment which is the subject of attack in this Court.
It is the subsequent commitment to which I ask leave to address myself at this time.
For after his original commitment at the District of Columbia General Hospital, that hospital reported a --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Could you start -- would you start again with those facts please, the procedural facts so we can have them all in mind?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I should be delighted to do so.
The petitioner had been charged for the violation of the Bad Check Law of the District of Columbia.
This happened on November 6, 1959.
At that time, upon arraignment in municipal court, he was not assisted by counsel.
The court entered a not guilty plea for him and committed him to the D.C. General Hospital for observation to determine his competency to stand trial upon that charge.
Now, on December 4, 1959, that hospital reported to the court that petitioner was of unsound mind and mentally incompetent to participate in his own defense.
Some time elapsed after that, approximately three weeks, and the hospital then reported a change in the petitioner's mental condition.

It reported that petitioner had sufficiently recovered to be capable of participating in his own defense, but that he had been suffering from a mental disease at the time of the crimes charged in the information and that the crimes if any, were probably the products of said disease.

I say “probably,” if Your Honors please, because there was no statement of certainty within the diagnostic view propounded by the Government's psychiatrist as reflected in his letter to the municipal court reproduced on page 26 of the transcript of the record.
The psychiatrist informed the municipal court in that letter that petitioner was suffering from a manic depressive psychosis.
However, the causal relationship between that disease and the criminal act set forth in the indictment was described in less than categorically unqualified terms.
The illness declared the doctor, and I quote him, “would particularly affect his judgment in regard to financial matters so that the crime charged would be a product of this mental disease.”

Now, it was on the basis of this certification that petitioner was brought before the municipal court again on December 29 as competent to stand trial upon the charges then pending against him, and he was then represented by counsel appointed by the municipal court.
Petitioner thereupon, acting through counsel, insistently and consistently sought to affect the withdrawal of the not guilty plea which had been entered for him and enter a guilty plea in its stead.
This, he was not allowed to do.
A trial was held over the petitioner's objection, obviously, upon --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I -- may I interrupt?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose the plea -- of guilty has been accepted, what procedure would have followed?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The defendant would've been subject to a maximum sentence of one year in the District of Columbia Penal System.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Two years?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Two years insofar as there were two crimes, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would the issue of insanity at all come into play?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The judge of course could have committed the individual defendant to a mental hospital under Section 301 if at the time of sentencing he had reason to believe that the individual defendant was incompetent to participate in the proceedings or appreciate the nature of the proceedings in which he was involved.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But responsibilities for the crime to which he pled guilty was not conducible.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Not as I see it, if Your Honor please.

At that stage, the defendant might have received a maximum of two years, one year each if consecutive sentences had been imposed or he could've been placed upon probation with provision for psychiatric out-patient treatment if the judge had considered that desirable.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How about probation condition upon voluntary commitment to in-patient treatment, commitment to an institution?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That could conceivably have taken place.

But the drastic difference between that procedure, Mr. Justice Stewart, and the procedure followed in this case is that the petitioner could have established his eligibility for release with the greatest of ease compared to the situation which he now find himself where his eligibility for release is dependent upon a showing by proof beyond all reasonable doubt under recent Court of Appeals decision that he is free of any abnormal mental condition and that he is not likely to engage in further check writing in the reasonably foreseeable future.
And I believe the consequences are very sharply different.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Suppose nobody's completely free of every abnormal mental condition, what's that mean?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The Court of Appeals has --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That bothers me.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The Court of Appeals has interpreted abnormal mental condition to cover apparently the length and depth of mental disorders listed in the American Psychiatric Association manual.

In a recent case, for example, the Court of Appeals declared that the mere fact that an individual suffered from a psychoneurosis, a condition which modern psychiatrists inform us is so widespread as to perhaps afflict 50-60% of the population if not more, is not eligible for release in St. Elizabeths if he cannot show that his psychoneurosis is not of such a nature as to prevent him from engaging in further check writing, the offense with which he was originally charged.

In other words, check writing proclivity stemming from a merely neurotic, as distinct from psychotic condition is sufficient to keep an individual at St. Elizabeths until such time as he's completely rid of it and the burden of establishing his eligibility for release is entirely upon him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is this the statute as construed by the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: This is the criminal statute in sharp contrast to the civil commitment statute where release procedures are infinitely more liberal.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Arens --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Mr. Arens -- go ahead.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Arens, I was going to ask you when court counsel was appointed then the defendant came into court and then asked permission to change his plea from not guilty to guilty, was it necessary for the court then to proceed with the trial or did the court have the power if it desired to do so, to direct that a civil proceeding be initiated to determine his sanity if the court believed that there was a question as to whether he actually was competent to proceed with the trial?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, there is no doubt in my mind at all that the municipal court had the power to dismiss the charges and recommend the initiation of civil commitment proceedings.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, did it have to dismiss the charges?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: For civil commitment proceedings to be initiated the charges would have to be dismissed under the civil commitment statute of the District of Columbia.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why?
I don't get it.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The District of Columbia statute, and I'm referring now to Title 21 of the D.C. Code, permits the initiation of civil commitment proceeding only in the absence of any criminal charges which --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It could be any criminal charge pending against the person, is that it?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is the way I understand it --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There must be no criminal charge pending if a civil proceeding is to be conducted, is that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Let me put it this way, if Your Honor please.
I know of no case in which civil commitment proceedings have been initiated pursuant to Title 21 of the D.C. Code where criminal charges were still pending against the individual defendant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if he doesn't do that, if the magistrate doesn't do that, he must accept a plea of guilty, although he had before him reliable indicia indicating mental disturbance at the time the crime was committed.
That's your position, is it not, under law?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: My position --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not questioning it.
I just want to know.
I'm in a state of confusion.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: This is part of my position.
I believe the individual defendant has a constitutional right to enter a guilty plea in order to avert the I'm -- involuntary imposition upon him of an insanity defense.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I didn't --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't -- I don't -- I'm not reaching the legal questions of my own legal thinking because I'm not yet clear what the situation is and therefore I'm much troubled here.
If a plea of guilty is offered, is tendered, the court must either accept it or out of hand dismiss the charge though he has no evidence that the man isn't guilty.
He must dismiss that out of hand in order to begin civil mental process, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: If civil commitment procedures are to be initiated, no criminal charges can be left pending.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore the alternative is to accept the plea of guilty, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is one alternative.
There's a further alternative, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.
The further alternative would be to put the Government to the proof.
Let them establish the commission of the particular offense, but prevent them from imposing an insanity defense, the successful assertion of which results in loss of liberty.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is the judge -- could the judge sua sponte have summoned or did he by chance, summoned the psychiatrist, take the witness stand, put him through a course of questioning.
Then conclude what he did conclude on the basis of the written report?
He could do that, could he?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Could the judge summon a psychiatrist independently for the purpose of asserting an insanity defense?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I respectfully submit that he could not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He could not?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But he did, didn't he?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: It isn't clear, Your Honor, if it was the judge or the prosecution which did that and I believe the Government has conceded that we do not know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?
I'm again -- I'm still more confused.
I thought you just said that the prosecution that there could be a trial of the issue of the claimed insanity making him irresponsible for the commission of the deed, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I did not say that.
I did say there was -- there were two alternatives.
One, the acceptance of the guilty plea or the dismissal of the charges in the initiation of civil commitment procedure --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you said there was a third.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: And the other possibility, if it please Your Honor, would be putting the Government to the proof in establishing the commission of the offense charged in the information.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then I must ask you this question.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: With this (Inaudible) -- I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose the Government had called this psychiatrist instead of having the municipal court judge act on the written report, suppose the Government said “Your Honor, I'd like to summon Dr. Jones”, and then put Dr. Jones who merely repeated verbatim what he had in his report.
Could the judge then act as he did?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, he could not.
I respectfully --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then what is the third alternative?
I don't understand it.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The third alternative is putting the government to its proof without putting -- with the caveat that the defendant be permitted to manage his own trial strategy and that an involuntary insanity defense not be imposed against -- upon us.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of the Government's proof, if the witnesses for the Government showed the commission of the act of writing a check against its official funds but further showed that the act was done under such circumstances as to show incontrovertibly that the man was insane when he did it, now -- then what would the judge have to do?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I respectfully submit that insofar as the defendant does not rely upon this testimony, this testimony cannot be used to affect his loss of liberty because it involves procedural irregularity striking at the heart of due process.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you think a judge, a conscientious judge, could --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is that to say that the court -- excuse me, excuse me, I think you were talking --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is that to say that the court may sentence a person whom the evidence shows to have been of unsound mind at the time of the commission of the crime?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: My answer to this Mr. Justice Whittaker is two-fold.

The traditional common law view has been that an individual defendant has a right to enter a guilty plea and as the Iowa Supreme Court has put it, reasons other than that he is guilty may induce a defendant to enter a guilty plea and therein, he must be permitted to judge for himself.
My second answer if it please the Court, is simple.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and does --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- your first answer carry with it that that's -- that that -- what you denominate the common law, the Iowa law is required by the due process clause?
Because we're not concerned here with what is common law or Iowa law.
We're concerned here in view of your submission that there was a deprivation of a constitutional right.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That's completely correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct, Your Honor.
And I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you say as a matter of constitutional due process that he may insist on -- for some -- what you call strategy and that is an ill sound to my ear but, the strategy is protected by the constitution.
This is a game that as a matter of due process he must be sent to jail although the Government is ready to prove whatever the adequacy of proof may be that in fact he was mentally irresponsible.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: My position if it please the Court, is that we cannot have an inversion of the roles of the prosecution and the defense.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But those are words.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: In which the defendant has no notice as to what it is that he is called upon to defend himself against and which he does not know that the trial in which he is specifically charged with uttering a check with intent to defraud is about to be transformed into an inquiry into his mental health.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was there a claim here by assigned counsel that he wants to disprove the substantiality of the psychiatrist's claim or testimony on the court?

As I understood your argument thus far it is that absolutely, a man has a right to insist on a plea of guilty being taken and entertained no matter what the showing of mentally responsibility of the act for which he's being -- to which he pled guilty.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is an alternate proposition, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, and that is conceding the right to the court for purposes of argument to reject a guilty plea.

We cannot concede the right to the court to impose a defense against the will of the individual defendant particularly if the successful assertion of that defense comports loss of liberty without notice, without an opportunity to rebut the defense which is in fact no defense at all but a method of inflicting a very serious sanction and without assistance of counsel --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The upshot of which is, he's rid of the charge of crime against him.
That is wiped out and he can now defend perhaps successfully that he's mentally unbalanced.
Those are the constitutional rights for which you claim.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But Mr. Arens, are you arguing that the Government used this criminal leads as the substitute for or to debate the civil process for examining that?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I do make that argument and I make it consistently with the view expressed by Judge McGarraghy in the District Court in granting the petition for habeas corpus in sustaining the writs.
Judge McGarraghy declared, “I don't believe that the municipal court had a right to convert this proceeding into a civil commitment proceeding which is what it did.
Therefore, I don't think the municipal court had jurisdiction to commit the petitioner to St. Elizabeths.”

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I go back to something you said earlier?
I want to make sure I understand it.
I understood you to say that there is no civil commitment proceeding possible in the District of Columbia where there is a criminal charge pending against a man.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is my understanding and I hope I have not misinformed --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now, does that mean --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: -- the Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Does that mean that in a case where a man has been convicted, no plea of insanity, no suggestion of insanity, he is committed to prison.
He then becomes insane in prison during the service of his sentence.
Is there no power of the warden to institute some kind of a proceeding to transfer him to an insane asylum?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Harlan, there is.
Section 302 of Title 24 of the District of Columbia Code makes it possible for any individual found guilty of crime while serving sentence to be transferred to a mental hospital.

Significantly however, if it please the Court, his confinement within that mental hospital would be limited to the term of his sentence and he would not be under the disadvantage that petitioner is in now.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You mean the hospital would have to release him after the term of his sentence even though he continues to be insane?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The hospital would have to release him, if Your Honor please, unless civil commitment proceedings were instituted and there would of course be no bar to the institution of civil commitment proceedings upon the expiration of the sentence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Arens, may I ask you this question.

When the court refused to accept the defendant's plea of guilty, was there any statement on his part that the reason he was not doing it was because he felt this man was more likely to be insane than guilty and that therefore he was offering the defense of not guilty by reason of insanity?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is substantially my understanding of what transpired.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it in the record?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did interpose?
Did the judge interpose a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, we have no transcript to the record in the municipal court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, wouldn't the minutes of the court show that?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I have not been able to obtain any reliable information on the subject.
There is no doubt in my mind the municipal court judge acted with the best of humanitarian --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I am not questioning that.

I'm not questioning that at all but I suppose the minutes of the court will show that the defense -- the defendant once pled not guilty and then that he offered to plead guilty and was denied that opportunity.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That much is shown in it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It is shown.
Now --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- is there anything in addition to that to show that the court itself interposed a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity for this defendant?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Well, Your Honor.
No, there is nothing in the record.
The only thing that is plain is that the defense of insanity was asserted for the petitioner either by the Government or by the court.
No formal insanity plea is required under the rules prevailing in the circuit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: And may I then say, reverting to the statement of facts that evidence was heard over the objection of the petitioner and this evidence included testimony by a government psychiatrist who testified substantially and afforded the hospital report which I have referred to.

As a pauper, the petitioner lacked opportunity of any independent psychiatric verification of the claims concerning as mental health which were propounded by the one psychiatrist who testified for the Government.
Accordingly, petitioner offered no expert evidence in rebuttal of the evidence of the insanity which had been thus presented.
Lack of facilities in municipal court for the procurement of qualified psychiatrist at Government expense has been repeatedly set forth below in briefs and has never been denied by the Government.
It cannot be asserted that petitioner's counsel requested independent psychiatric scrutiny but had he done so, it would have been a futile gesture.
At the conclusion of this trial, the Chief Judge --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they -- that he did not request it.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is no evidence --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So far as --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: -- to indicate that he had requested it.
I merely say that had he requested it there, it would have been a futile gesture in the absence of any facilities on the part of the municipal court for rendering services of this kind.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Mr. Arens, what would've been your position, your constitutional position, had there been a plea of insanity imposed here and the same procedure followed under the statute?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe that a defendant has a right not to have any defense imposed upon him.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No, no.
I meant supposing he had voluntarily entered a plea or his counsel had (Inaudible)-- a plea of in -- not guilty by reason of insanity.
Then the Court had held him not guilty by a reason of insanity and that then follow the procedure under the statute, would you have a case?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Then, if Your Honor please, most, though not all of my procedural objections to what took place in municipal court would have been avoided.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, would that have been a constitutional proceeding?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe it would've been a constitutional proceeding up to a point.

The objection to the proceeding would then have come at a later stage significantly at the point where the commitment of the defendant was made without affording him an opportunity to show cause why commitment should be denied because of an improvement in his mental state and because of the fact that he was no longer ill or dangerous to himself or others.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is your -- your basic constitutional position as I understand it from your colloquy with Justice Brennan is that he was committed to St. Elizabeths without any determination of insanity.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now, had there been a voluntary plea of not guilty by a reason of insanity and an acquittal by that reason, would that have amounted to a finding that he was insane?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it would not because under Davis against United States decided by this Court, an acquittal by reason of insanity amounts to nothing more than a finding of a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: A reasonable doubt, exactly.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: And accordingly the commitment would still have been objectionable not for lack of a fair hearing and the imposition of an insanity defense without notice and without opportunity to rebut.

But for lack of affording the defendant an opportunity to show cause why commitment should be denied because notwithstanding any previously existing mental state, he was not as of the time of the adjudication --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But what I am trying --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: -- was mentally ill.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What I am trying to get at is the reach of your constitutional position.
Is it that even under the hypothetical case that I put that that would render the application of the statute unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Or, is your position limited to the situation where there has been no voluntary plea of insanity imposed and one simply entered by the court.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Our position goes all the way, if Your Honor please.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: All --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The statute which authorizes deprivation of human liberty without affording the target of the particular proceeding an opportunity to show cause why commitment should be denied strikes me as repugnant to the Due Process Clause is --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Arens, I'm not sure I understood you, but did you say that a plea of not guilty under the law of the District of Columbia embraces a defense of insanity?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it does.
There is no requirement for a special plea of not guilty by reason of insanity.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well then, a plea of not guilty here was in fact a plea of not guilty for any cause including insanity.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes -- it could've been.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now one more question please.
I understood you a while ago to say that the trial judge might have dismissed this proceeding.
How could he have done that in the absence of evidence showing illegal irresponsibility for the client?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: He could conceive they have dismissed the proceedings as a matter of individual discretion.

He could have stated that the individual defendant although guilty of the factual transaction lacked a particular intent to defraud and he might have avoided inquiry into his mental health under the criminal insanity law with consequences as far reaching as the ones which he faces in this case.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I suppose -- I would think that you could've given the judge an easier route, if I understand the statute correctly, namely to accept his plea, send him to St. Elizabeths, alert the warden, the warden finds he's presently insane, he can transfer him to St. Elizabeths to the expiration of his sentence and then a civil commitment proceeding.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There's no question --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could the court have done that?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There's no question about that upon --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, why do you have to go through this other (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: If I understand Your Honor correctly, he certainly could've been given a determinate prison sentence.
The warden could've been alerted concerning his mental condition.

He could've been transferred pursuant to Section 302 to St. Elizabeths Hospital, although his confinement therein would have been restricted to the term of his sentence, or he could've been placed on probation with the requirement that he undergo psychiatric treatment on an out-patient basis which is a medical matter, may have been what was indicated for the petitioner was never afforded --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Isn't that a much more direct way of reaching the problem that you're complaining about as going through the mechanics of dismissing a criminal proceeding that's --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- undismissable?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe this would probably have been preferable.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Arens, may I ask you this question.
Is there not another alternative?

Could not the judge before he placed him on trial at the suggestion of the prosecution or the hospital or anybody else have dismissed this criminal case against him and then had a civil proceeding to determine his sanity without having to put him in jeopardy?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Without any question at all, Mr. Justice Warren.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And then after the civil proceeding was over, if he was found to be sane then they could've charged him again with the same crime, tried him, and convicted him.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Precisely and may I say, if the Court -- if it please the Court, that dismissals of proceedings particularly on the municipal court level are a common place occurrence.

A first-offender almost invariably succeeds in having the charges against him dismissed if there is any showing at all that he has a job, that he has a residence, and that he is vouched for by citizens of some reputation.
It is amazing that in this case in which the Government asserts concern for the rights of this particular individual no dismissal of proceedings took place.

The individual was forced to trial and committed to St. Elizabeths until such time as he was certified by the hospital authorities has recovered from his mental illness and not likely to be dangerous to himself or others in the reasonable future.
And there was no finding by the municipal court as to the petitioner's then existing state of mind or social dangerousness.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who can initiate an involuntary commitment proceeding under the District of Columbia law?Can anybody or does it have to be a member of the --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I can --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- his family or what?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: As a general matter of practice, members of the family take the initiative but I can vouch to the Court from the fact the government has on numerous occasions successfully initiated commitment proceedings including commitment proceedings in cases in which I have represented certain clients.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What does the statute provide, do you happen to know, does it -- as to who can initiate the proceeding?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The statute permits the Government to initiate, specifically permits the Government, the police to initiate civil commitment proceedings under certain circumstances.

And in one particular case, United States versus Haggard, Judge Youngdahl dismissed a murder charge pending against that defendant and then upon my recommendation signed a civil commitment order upon a petition which I had prepared.
The Government would've been in an identical position and could've done the same thing and in fact it has in similar cases.

But if I may sum the factual situation of this case up, neither the petitioner nor his counsel raised the issue of insanity, neither he nor his counsel introduced any evidence bearing on the issue of insanity and no motion or request was made in his behalf for a finding of not guilty by reason of insanity.
Every move toward that finding was resisted.

However, the presiding judge on the basis of the testimony of a government psychiatrist was not rebutted, found the petitioner not guilty on the ground of insanity and committed -- affected his commitment in the manner aforesaid.

Significantly, there was no finding petitioner's insanity as of the time of the adjudication nor was a hearing afforded the petitioner in which he might have shown cause why confinement was improper for practical legal or medical reasons thus (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did the Government -- did the Government offer this proof of insanity in its case in chief or in rebuttal?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: In the case in chief, if Your Honor please.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I thought you (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: If I understand --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought you told us earlier we don't know who.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is quite correct.

It was either the court or the Government but as I understand it, there was -- the petitioner never denied the writing of the bad checks and accordingly I do not think there was any conflict on that point.
There was certainly no conflict as to psychiatric testimony since petitioner had no psychiatrist available.
We do not know whether the psychiatrist was called by the Government or the court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do I rightly infer that what the municipal court did was warrant it under the statute and that you read -- you reach the constitutionality of the statute, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I do not believe the statute authorized the involuntary imposition of the insanity defense.
I do not believe Congress contemplated a situation in which an individual who had not affirmatively --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that's construed by the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: As construed by the Court of Appeals, the action of the municipal court was warranted by the statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that means -- that means that in effect the Court of Appeals construed the statute to lay down as a rule of law that the duty of proving mental responsibility is an affirmative duty on the part of the prosecution.
That's what is implied.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think it's unconstitutional to make any such requirement that the prosecution has the duty of affirmatively proving mental capacity?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe it is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know this Court has said that it's not unconstitutional to do the reverse but I wonder if we've reached the point where it's unconstitutional to put the burden of proving mental responsibility upon the prosecution whether that violates due process.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No Your Honor.
Having the re -- having the prosecution prove mental responsibility or lack of responsibility in no way violates due process.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what he did here.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Provided the prosecution does so in a procedure which can be denominated as fair and rational and provided the consequences of the particular defense are not as onerous and punitive as they turn out to be in the case at bar.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In other words, it's unfair and irrational to put this extra burden on the prosecution instead of resting on the presumption it entered by the decision, part of presumption that is entered.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I respectfully submit that it is unfair and irrational to do it under a standard of proof which permits the forfeiture of human liberty upon the basis of a doubt concerning mental health.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well you're not here because the record doesn't permit you to be here.
In this Court, there is no record on which to base it.
That in fact the proof was lacking in those -- essential that what we call due process.
This case isn't here, but there is no basis for finding that the prosecution didn't maintain its responsibility of proving that mental responsibility.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: May I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You are here on the assumption and the inevitable influence that the prosecution undertook that burden, that it established it, that the judgment warranted in finding it -- what it established and that it violates due process to put this extra burden on the prosecution.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: May I address myself to the points so cogently raised by Mr. Justice Frankfurter as follows.

Suppose that in a criminal -- in a particular case in which commitment is involved, the -- a jury trial was held and suppose that a psychiatrist provides evidence infinitely more persuasive and unequivocal in the evidence provided in this case as to the mental illness of the defendant and the causal relationship of that mental illness were the crime charged.

And suppose the judge thereupon charges the jury that commitment to a mental hospital, and let us assume this is a civil commitment proceeding, is possible upon the showing of nothing more than reasonable doubt concerning his mental health.
Will this Court uphold loss of human liberty under a standard of this particular type regardless of the weight of the evidence?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You're reading a totally different question.
That's the -- that's like our recent Thompson case.
What you've now said was -- there was no basis for such a finding by the court.
I can understand that claim but as I also understand it, we haven't got the basis on which to pass on it.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Mr. --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I thought your point was that there's no finding at all.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: There is no finding in this case at all by the judge that the individual was insane as of the time of the adjudication.
Implicit of course an acquittal by reason of insanity is there was a reasonable doubt as to the defendant's mental health as of the time of the commission of the crimes alleged in the information.

And I respectfully submit that forfeiture of human liberty upon the basis of a reasonable doubt in a proceeding in which the defense is forced upon the defendant without notice as to the consequences and without an opportunity to rebut what is not a defense but an offense --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is there --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: -- offends due process.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you find anything in the legislative history of this statute that would prevent a reading that it was intended to apply only in a situation where there had been a defense of insanity interposed?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
The Senate and House Reports --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What are you reading from?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I'm reading from page 53 --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Of your --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: -- of my brief.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Your brief?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: If Your Honor please, refer to the situation where the accused has pleaded insanity as the defense to a crime and the jury has found the defendant was in fact insane at the time the crime was committed.

May I say that at the time of the enactment of Section 301, Congress knew of no single example in which an involuntary imposition of an insanity defense had been tolerated by the courts and it's concerned at that time as its well-known, was that the liberal laws rule of criminal responsibility presented by the Durham case would enable numerous dangerous criminals who had affirmatively taken advantage of what was thought to be a possible loophole to roam the streets and endanger the public safety.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was the Durham case the mode of power behind the statute?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe without any question, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well that mode of power behind making it mandatory.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's required, that I gather, to the discretion.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Arens, would you please enlighten me.
You answer Justice Douglas a minute ago that there was no finding that the judge didn't find that he was not guilty.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, I did not say that Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What did you say?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I said no -- there wasn't --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: No, there has been -- no finding of insanity.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is completely correct, Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that's what the -- page 9, please explain what that means.
Is it the direction that the superintendent think of then?
The court having found the accused not guilty on the ground that he was insane at the time of the commission of the offense.
Isn't that a finding of insanity?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I've --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not saying that there's a -- that it's justified that there was proof of it but there is certainly as a finding, if I understand what that word means.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe, if it please the Court, that this comports nothing more than a finding of the reasonable doubt concerning insanity as of the time of the commission of the alleged offense as distinct from the time of the petitioner's commitment to St. Elizabeths hospital.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does the Government agree with you?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I'm quite sure the Government does not agree with me on this point.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Arens --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, the hospital agrees with you to some extent at least, did it not?
Didn't they make a differentiation between his mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense and as of the time of the trial?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, indeed --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they say that he had improve greatly and that he was then able to understand his surroundings and to cooperate with counsel in the conduct of his defense?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, indeed, Mr. Chief Justice Warren.

The D.C. General Hospital, after having originally declared this individual to be too sick to stand trial subsequently announced that he was then free of such mental disease as would render him incompetent to participate in proceedings.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's on page 24 of the record (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And What you are saying is that it's unconstitutional for the Congress of the United States to say if a man is found insane at the time of the -- insane for the transaction for which he's tried and he's acquitted because of that mental state, Congress of the United States can't say you -- that the judge should send him for observation at a hospital for his mental state.
That's your ultimate position, is it?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I don't think it is.

The situation would be very different if the statute were to provide for example, that after an acquittal by reason of insanity, an individual defendant were to be committed for an extremely short period of observation, after which a report had to be returned to the Court certifying as to what his mental state then was, the commitment which not to express after an insanity acquittal is indefinite and to establish it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is separate because there's always the opportunity for relief --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The opport --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in terms of his commitment so states, “each in your custody on guilty shall be discharged by due course of law.”
As always, an accessibility to the Court as to -- in every case of mental confinement.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, it will not do to say that because habeas corpus may be resorted to in the future, liberty may be deprived at a particular time without due process of law and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Must you say 10 days, a month?
The whole point is that this is an observation in the hospital.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I know, but in order to determine what to treat or how to treat, you must observe.
This is an effort to ascertain facts on the basis of which rational judgments can be based.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor please, the District Court has refused to consider habeas corpus petitions which have been filed as long as six months after an acquittal on the ground --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that isn't the case we have before us.
We have this statute and this action.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I was wondering if we have before us at all the release part of this statute about which I for one, would have considerable doubts, but do we have that before us here?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Insofar as this particular individual has been forced into what the Court of Appeals has called a special class of individuals who may not be released in the manner in which individuals who'd been committed pursuant to civil commitment law may be released.
We do have --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But has it -- this man hasn't tried to be released, has he?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he has tried twice to be released.

There's no longer mentally ill and he has not been able to meet the exacting standards of the Court of Appeals' standards which require that he prove beyond reasonable doubt that St. Elizabeths was arbitrary and capricious in failing to certify that his psychoneurotic propensity will not in the reasonably foreseeable future result in further check writing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, if we were reviewing his --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There's no (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- the denial of his release, it would be one thing.
We'd have that before us.
We have those release provisions before us and I under -- you just said he's been denied at least twice and has he tested this out judicially?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: No, Your Honor, that has not been tested.
I merely --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then we'd have those provisions before us but we'd have now before us something quite different, don't we?
We don't have those before us.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe we have an individual who has been forced into an intolerable position as a result of the involuntary imposition of the insanity defense.
Part of the realities of this position is his inability to secure a release under standards prevailing in the civil commitment field.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you say “involuntary” all you're saying is that before a judge accepted a plea of guilty, he wanted to have established and put upon the prosecution the burden of establishing that he's to send to jail a man of a charge, may have been mentally irresponsible.
That's what you mean by involuntary.
That's all you can mean in the context of these facts.
Of course, that's involuntary, in that entire control of the judicial proceedings are not in the hands of the defendant where an issue is his mental responsibility.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That is certainly correct, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.
But that is both extraordinary and unprecedented for this or any other court to countenance the imposition of the defense which is spurned by the defendant.
And no rule appears to be better settled but that constitutional defenses and privileges are subject to waiver.

And may I say, if the privilege against self-incrimination were not subject to waiver, we would be preventing defendants from taking the stand and testifying their own behalf and providing a rational account of the transaction.
I believe we would be striking a due process of law.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It isn't so extraordinary to me since this is exactly the English provision as a result of the most thorough investigation by a royal conviction, a thorough examination of the House of Commerce before the Act of 1959 was passed.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor please, I respectfully take issue with Mr. Justice Frankfurter on the English position, which is set forth in our brief and which his quite unmistakable.
The Eng --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It decided Section 60 Subsection 2 of that statute?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: If the Court will indulge me for a moment, I will attempt to -- I have cited, if Your Honor please, Section 443 of the Royal Commission Report on Capital Punishment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I am talking about the Act of 1978 Elizabeth Protecting Chapter 72, Section 60 Subdivision 2.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I'm not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In which gives exactly what you've -- so far as I can read it, so should I read it.

The first one deals with the powers of court after conviction, Section 2 Subdivision 2, where a person is charged before a magistrate's court with any act or omission of a -- as an offense, the Court would have power on convicting him of that offense to make an order under Subsection 1 of this Section.
Then, if the court is satisfied that the accused did the act or made the omission charged, the court may if it sees fit make such an order without convicting him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well after all we're not trying him under English procedure, are we?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you this question?

Referring back to the question of Mr. Justice Stewart about whether this case might more properly be here on a writ of habeas corpus to release him because of his penal -- present mental condition, would you be in any better position in that kind of a proceeding to raise these questions that you are now raising here than you are in this proceeding?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Yes, undoubtedly.

We could make a frontal attack upon the release procedures of the district commitment law if we had alleged in the case which finally came before this Court that he had recovered from all mental illness.

All we can allege at this particular time is that he was put in a position of severe disadvantage and that -- but one of the disadvantages is the difficulty which he would inevitably encounter if he were to seek release at a future time.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: The release procedure --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: My point Mr. Arens is this.
Could you in such a proceeding raise these procedural questions as to his commitment to the institution?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I don't believe so.
I believe this would be independent --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't believe you could, so if you can't raise it in this kind of a proceeding, you couldn't raise it in any proceeding, could you?

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: I believe that is stating the position of petitioner with perfect precision.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I wasn't suggesting Mr. Arens that you couldn't raise most of the questions you've raised.
I was simply suggesting that the release provisions of the statute are not directly an issue in this case.

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Not directly an issue.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If you brought the kind of action suggested by the Chief Justice, you could raise those but you couldn't probably raise some of the ones that you're raising in this case --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- (Inaudible) to the other cases.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Arens, we've taken so much of your time in argument that I'm (Inaudible) answering -- passing you questions that I'm going to give you five more minutes in rebuttal to --

turn.speaker: richard_arens
turn.label: Mr. Richard Arens
turn.text: Thank you very much, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in which you may be able to sum up your argument.
Mr. Marshall.

turn.speaker: burke_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Burke Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
There are a number of issues that are raised in the brief by Mr. Arens' argument.
I would like to separate them into two categories because I think that they will be easier to deal with in that fashion.
One category has to do with the trial court's conduct, what the Chief Justice just referred to as the claimed procedural irregularities in the case.
These issues have been put by Mr. Arens largely in constitutional terms.

But I think that the fact is that many or most of them are not necessarily constitutional, that is that the Court could deal with them in the matter of administering federal judicial system and the system of justice in the federal courts without giving them a constitutional dimension.
The other issues have to do with the constitutionality of the statute and these are necessarily constitutional.

They depend -- they turn on the question of whether Congress acted so irrationally in passing the mandatory commitment statute in the district that the statute has to be declared unconstitutional under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

Now, turning first to the procedural side of the case, I think it should be kept in mind that there is no question but that this procedure against Mr. Lynch started with the commission of two criminal acts.
There is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's begging the question as to they're criminal if he was sane, they're not criminal if he was insane.

turn.speaker: burke_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Burke Marshall
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Stewart, I should say two acts which were criminal unless he was not responsible --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Unless he had defenses --

turn.speaker: burke_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Burke Marshall
turn.text: -- criminal (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- which made them non-criminal.

turn.speaker: burke_marshall
turn.label: Mr. Burke Marshall
turn.text: They are two acts prohibited by a criminal statute, Mr. Justice Stewart, and the question was whether or not he was criminally responsible for them.
I meant that they did not start with him sitting in his home and being brought in to a -- by the Government.
They started with a commission of an act which is prohibited by a criminal statute and the question was what consequences resulted from that.
The other fact is that there is no question on this record as to the -- Mr. Lynch's insanity at the time (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess now.
